comments.raw_text:
Right now, Windows Vista and 7 use GDI to render their UI elements (titlebar, menus, etc). We use whatever we've been configured to use for a given font; in most cases at those sizes, it's GDI-style, but this might not always be the case.

I'm wondering if we should always unconditionally use GDI-style rendering in menus and other toplevel user interface elements, because right now we don't use the same style as the rest of the system.

This has its plusses and minuses, so I'm also asking for UX input. The plus is that we would fit in with the rest of the system, but the minus is that we wouldn't (necessarily) be doing the same as the rest of the application. (However, note that that's what IE does too.)

Also, I don't know that we know what Microsoft will do with toplevel UI font rendering in Windows 8 and beyond, so whatever we do might need to be changed anyways.

comments.raw_text:
(In reply to comment #1)

Hi Alex.  The term "non-native font rendering" is somewhat meaningless here, there are a large set of parameters that affect text rendering on Windows, there isn't a single "native" way.  The GDI classic vs. DirectWrite rendering modes affect the contrast of the subpixel antialiasing of text but the degree to which rendering differences exist depends upon the font (e.g. Segoe UI vs. Calibri vs. Verdana or Tahoma).  There are also elements in the UI that still use *grayscale* anti-aliasing (e.g. tooltips, status overlay) and some users have reported other elements as well (see bug 659211).  This is leftover from the work on the layer system introduced in FF4.

The contrast differences between GDI and DirectWrite rendering modes particularly affects users using the 96-dpi UI setting ("small") as opposed to higher DPI settings.
